Just watching this and I realised there is a way to measure the speed of a spaceship travelling through space. A thought experiment I imagined utilises a device which uses an atom as the harmonic oscillator. Send the atom within a closed vacuum detecting the frequency it rebounds off each of 6 walls in a cube. It will begin at a fixed speed at an arbitrarily set space as close as possible to zero movement. The pattern of how the atom bounces should have a distinguishable form. Then as the ship accelerates the atom will take a longer time to bounce between the forward wall and the wall to the rear relative to acceleration. Why? Because the faster the acceleration the more spacetime fabric the atom has to move through to reach the front wall so the timing will appear to slow and of course conversely the bounce back will accellerate. This is because the speed of energy/light is constant in a vacuum relative to an object so the atom being energy/"encapsulated light" will travel through the spacetime fabric at a fixed speed regardless of the speed of the spaceship. As the spaceship approaches the natural speed of the atom it will appear that the atom slows down and would theoretically stop if the spaceship reached the speed of the atom. There we have it a speedometer for a spaceship. Finding the particle most stable would be the only minor problem to overcome, a particle without an electron would be ideal but perhaps not as big a problem as I first thought if there was an electron or electrons in the shell. A hydrogen atom maybe??

Einstein's equivalence (20:25) that inertial mass and gravitational mass are the same.
When you accelerate an object that acceleration acts on all parts of the object to the same extent. However when an object is in a gravitational field the effect differs due to some parts of the object being closer to the centre of gravity than other parts.
So this equivalence only works for points, not for real-life objects with finite dimensions.
In theory, at least, it should be possible to detect this change in gravitational attraction across the size of an object. While the effect will be very, very, small it would still exist.

Here is a cool trick you can do at home: try substituting “pounds and ounces” for “mass” in these equations. Try it for yourself and you will see that it will make no difference in the results. This is the source of the problem Vera Rubin uncovered when she looked through a telescope. Her discovery was explained away by saying she verified dark matter exists. But what if another woman comes along, another Vera Rubin, who looks through a telescope and then decides that the stars in the inner region of galaxies do not travel fast enough? Then what do we do? Vera did not actually verify the existence of dark matter. Instead, she uncovered a problem with the equations for gravity. These equations simply describe the balance of two opposing types of gravity. If we are afraid to to correctly identify these kinds of problems, then we will find ourselves trapped in endless snipe hunts for things like dark matter and dark energy. I know what some of you are thinking after what I just said... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lj60OAh7O5U

We do understand electromagnetism very well because James Clerk Maxwell got his equations right, perhaps by good luck. Back then it was easier to identify magnetism and electric charge as energy. It was not so obvious that weight and mass are also manifestations of another type of energy. Today we are still struggling with gravity because the equations are problematic. If we are to understand gravity correctly – for both it's positive and negative aspects - then it seems the best way to do this is have equations for gravity structured similar to Maxwell's equations. Isaac Newton was a brilliant man, but today we have much more insight and knowledge than what scientists and mathematicians had even fifty years ago. As we apply our new knowledge, many of these old equations will need to be, and should be, updated or changed or replaced over time. Consequently, all mathematical equations based on our current understanding of gravity and are thus suspect, and subject to change.

I think Newton's greatest achievement was his calculus. Calculus is compatible with the universe because it is infinity-compatible. It works very well with the smooth structure of space as it can be used to describe an infinite amount of points. His equations might shift and change over time, but his calculus will not.

I started off with rockets with my kids when they were young by building a computer model to help with optimisation - propellant v weight and so on. The whole thing is so much fun and it is very cross-curricular aimed at getting people into physics from K to 12 and beyond. The Water Rocket Computer Model allows you to launch from any planet's (arbitrary, in the case of gas planets) surface by changing G and the gasses and so on. http://www.wrcm.grosse.is-a-geek.com/ produces graphs of altitude, velocity, acceleration against time and downrange distance. It is all calculated on the server (I wrote the cgi program) so you don't need anything more than a web browser to run it.

Having recently rewatched Feynman’s lectures on beginning physics I am very pleased to let you know I think yours are obviously more fun but also better, more easily understood, and engaging to the point that we can agree that physics is phun to learn or even re- learn. Thanks for doing these.

One note: due to Einstein showing the relationship between energy and mass (E=mc^2) we know that energy and mass are two sides of the same coin. So when she said that dark matter made up around 23% of the mass in the universe that figure included all energy (and thus dark energy) too. In that context "regular" matter, like stars and planets, only makes up a little under 5% of the energy/matter in the universe. So there is actually 5 to 6 times as much dark matter as there is "regular" matter.

You mention gravitational waves travel at the same speed as light (in a vacuum, in a previous lesson I think you said it varies, and potentially the key to my question below). I, for no valid reason, believe light is not travelling at the max speed possible. Said speed is just a limitation of light but there could be something that travels faster. We can't see it of course because our eyes work on the basis of light.

I have asked a few if gravitational waves travel faster than light but am yet to get a satisfactory answer. I base this question on my extremely feeble brain recognising that light arrived 1.7 seconds later than a gravitational wave from the same location (if I understand correctly the observable gravity actually stopping). Kind of makes sense, then, that the gravitational wave was travelling faster. I am of course referring to the neutron star merger in NGC4993 and GW170817. The best information I can get is from Ask Ethan. Where the explanation is stuff got in the way, slowing light I think (by not being in a vacuum), at the point of explosion. So essentially light left (crudely speaking) 1.7 seconds later than the gravity wave stopped.

Are you able to explain this in the moderately easy way you explain all your lessons? Probably an entire lesson after your 101 syllabus has finished. Or maybe I'm right and the speed of light in a vacuum is not the limitation of speed we have been taught. ;)

Hi Diana, are you not oversimplifying Newton’s discovery? Gravity was known before Newton (see Galileo’s work) but was thought to apply only on Earth. Ancient scholars believed there were two sets of the laws of physics: one for the Earth and one for the Cosmos. With objects on Earth having naturally downward motion (i.e. gravity) and objects in space having a naturally circular motion. Newton’s is a law of UNIVERSAL gravity, meaning Newton postulated that gravity also works in space and unified the two domains of different laws of physics. (And that's a cooler story IMO).

Dark matter is simply matter in a different dimension. We are only conscious in 3 dimensions but there are many others.  This also explains a large amount of quantum theory. For example quantum entanglement. The particles can be far apart in the 3 conscious dimensions (x,y, & z) but they haven’t moved in another dimension (for example ‘q’)
